speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents in the emergency department. I’ve read that you came in because your right leg has been swelling. Can you tell me when you first noticed the swelling and how it’s changed over the last few days?

speaker: PATIENT
text: It started a few days ago and just kept getting bigger. It’s my whole right leg, from the thigh down. It feels heavy and hurts when I walk. I just had this new dialysis line put in on the right side not long ago, so I was worried it might be related.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Thanks, that helps. Any redness, warmth, or drainage around the catheter site in your right groin? Any fevers, chills, shortness of breath, or chest pain?

speaker: PATIENT
text: No, the skin around the line looks okay to me—no pus or anything. I haven’t had fevers or chills. I do feel some mild pressure in my chest sometimes and I’ve had a dry cough, but I’ve had that for a bit. Breathing is okay.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Got it. I see from your chart that you have HIV with a low CD4 count, are on hemodialysis for kidney failure, and you recently had a left femoral dialysis catheter removed for a MRSA infection and a right femoral catheter placed. You also have a history of atrial fibrillation and post‑herpetic neuralgia around your right eye. Is that all still correct?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, that’s right. They took out the left line because it got infected with MRSA. Now I’ve got the right one. I’m on dialysis three times a week. My HIV doctor just restarted my meds recently. My heart goes into A‑fib sometimes, but they told me it’s been okay lately. And my right eye and forehead still hurt from the shingles I had there.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: In the ER your vital signs have been stable, but your labs show your potassium is a bit high and your creatinine is up, which we expect with your kidney failure. Your blood counts are low but similar to your baseline. We’re also concerned about a possible clot in the veins of your right leg or around the catheter, so we’re going to get an ultrasound of the leg veins and some more blood work. We’ll also give you pain medicine while we sort this out.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I just don’t want another infection like last time. And this leg really hurts. I’ll do the tests you need.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: I’m the attending physician here. Your initial labs show a potassium of about 5.5 and creatinine around 7.3, which fits with needing dialysis soon. Your hemoglobin is in the 8 range and hematocrit mid‑20s, similar to your usual anemia. We’ll coordinate with nephrology to get you dialyzed on your regular schedule and watch your potassium closely.

speaker: PATIENT
text: As long as I can still get my dialysis, that’s fine. I usually go three times a week. I’m just scared this swelling means something is wrong with the new line.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: That’s understandable. The ultrasound we ordered will look for clots in the leg veins and around the catheter. If we see a clot, we’ll talk about blood thinners. If we don’t, we’ll still consider whether there could be a clot higher up that the ultrasound can’t see and may need more imaging.

speaker: NURSE
text: I’m your nurse. I’m going to give you some morphine now for the leg pain, and we’ll get you ready to go down for the ultrasound. If you feel more short of breath or the pain suddenly worsens, please hit the call button right away.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you. The pain is pretty bad, so I’m glad for something to take the edge off.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your right leg ultrasound is back. It shows no deep vein thrombosis in the right leg veins, and they can see your hemodialysis catheter entering the right common femoral vein without any clot around the visible part of the line.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So there’s no clot in the leg? Then why is it so swollen?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: The ultrasound can’t see the entire course of the catheter higher up in the pelvis. Because of your symptoms and your history of a catheter‑related clot across the atrial septal defect on your last admission, we’re going to get a CT scan of your pelvis with contrast to look at the larger veins around the catheter.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I remember they told me last time the line went through a hole in my heart and had a clot on it. They put me on heparin for a couple of days. I really don’t want that to happen again.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Your CT pelvis shows a lot of right leg edema. The tunneled dialysis catheter takes up most of the right external iliac vein, which makes it hard to see if there’s a clot right around the line, but the other pelvic veins look open. Given your swelling and the limited view, we’re going to treat this as a likely clot around the catheter and start you on a heparin drip, then transition you to warfarin.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So you’re sure there’s a clot even though they couldn’t see it clearly? And this time you want me on warfarin long‑term? I was scared of that before.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We can’t see the clot directly because the catheter fills most of that vein on CT, but with your symptoms and risk factors, the safest course is to treat it as a clot. On your last admission, cardiology recommended long‑term anticoagulation because of your atrial fibrillation and the catheter‑related clot, but it wasn’t started due to concerns about adherence and your preference. Given this new presumed clot, we strongly recommend warfarin now, and we’ll arrange close INR monitoring through your dialysis unit.

speaker: PATIENT
text: If it will keep me from getting more clots or a stroke, I’ll try it. I just need help keeping track of all these meds and blood tests.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’ve started your heparin drip through your IV. We’ll be drawing your PTT blood test regularly to make sure the dose is in the right range. If you notice any bleeding from your gums, nose, or in your stool, or if you get a bad headache, please tell us right away.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, I’ll let you know. I bruise easily already, so I’m a little nervous about more blood thinners.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: This morning’s labs show your hemoglobin is about 8.9 and hematocrit 28.3, similar to your baseline anemia. Your white count is around 4, and your platelets are normal. Your potassium is 5.7, creatinine 7.9, and BUN 59, so nephrology will dialyze you today. Your CD4 count is 39 with a CD4 percentage of 4% and a low CD4/CD8 ratio, consistent with advanced AIDS, so we’ll continue your antiretroviral regimen and prophylactic antibiotics.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So my blood counts are about the same as usual? And I keep taking the HIV meds and the Bactrim and azithromycin like at home?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, your counts are similar to your baseline. We’re continuing abacavir, atazanavir with ritonavir, and emtricitabine, as well as Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin weekly. We’ll also keep your aspirin, cinacalcet at a reduced dose, sevelamer, nephrocaps, duloxetine, and your pain and itch medicines.

speaker: CONSULT
text: Hi, I’m from the nephrology team. We’ll continue your hemodialysis on your usual schedule while you’re here. Today we’ll dialyze you and give you epoetin for anemia, ferric gluconate for iron, and doxercalciferol for your secondary hyperparathyroidism, along with heparin during dialysis and a heparin dwell for the catheter.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I usually feel better after dialysis. Will that help the swelling in my leg too?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Dialysis will remove extra fluid, which often helps with swelling. In your case, the leg edema is also likely related to the catheter and possible clot, but we’ve already seen that your swelling improves after dialysis sessions, and we expect that to continue.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your morning labs show your potassium is down to 4.8 and your creatinine is about 4.9 after dialysis. Your hemoglobin is 9.0 and hematocrit 27.5. The doctors are happy with these numbers. We’ll keep checking your PTT and INR while you’re on heparin and starting warfarin.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Good to hear. My leg does feel a bit less tight today. But now my right eye is puffy and stuck shut in the morning with some gunk. It worries me because of the shingles I had there before.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: I see the swelling and some discharge around your right eye. Given your history of herpes ophthalmicus in that area, we’re going to have ophthalmology see you. In the meantime, we’ll start an antibiotic eye ointment and valacyclovir by mouth to cover both bacterial conjunctivitis and possible viral reactivation.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I really don’t want that shingles in my eye again. It was awful. I’ll use whatever drops or pills you give me.

speaker: CONSULT
text: I’m from ophthalmology. Your right eye has some periorbital swelling and purulent discharge, consistent with conjunctivitis. Because of your prior herpes in this area, we agree with starting polymyxin/bacitracin ophthalmic ointment and a 7‑day course of valacyclovir. We’ve also sent tests from a forehead lesion for HSV and VZV; so far, the direct antigen tests and cultures have not shown herpes or varicella‑zoster.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So it’s more like an eye infection than shingles coming back? That’s a relief. I’ll keep using the ointment and pills.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your coagulation labs overnight show your PTT is in the 60–70 second range on the heparin drip, which is therapeutic, and your INR is still around 1.0. We’ll keep the heparin going while we increase your warfarin dose to get your INR into the 2–3 range.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’ve heard people say their blood gets ‘too thin’ on these meds. Are my numbers okay, or is there a risk of bleeding?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Right now your PTT is high because of the heparin, which is what we want while we’re bridging you. Your INR is just starting to rise with warfarin and is not yet in the target range. We’re watching closely and adjusting doses daily. We’ll stop the heparin once your INR has been in the therapeutic range twice in a row, and we’ll continue to monitor for any signs of bleeding.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I’ll keep an eye out for any bleeding and tell you if I notice anything.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your labs this morning show your hemoglobin is about 8.9, hematocrit 28.1, white count 3.7, and platelets 182. Your creatinine is 6.6 and BUN 43, potassium 4.6, and your INR is 1.7 with a PTT of about 86. We’ve adjusted your heparin and the doctors increased your warfarin dose yesterday.

speaker: PATIENT
text: My leg looks almost back to normal now. The swelling is way down. Does that mean the clot is getting better?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, the fact that your right leg edema has largely resolved, especially after dialysis, is a good sign that the circulation is improving. We’re going to continue the heparin until your INR is solidly in the therapeutic range, then stop the drip and keep you on warfarin alone.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s good news. My eye also feels a lot better—just a little puffiness left.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’re checking back from ophthalmology. Your periorbital swelling has almost completely resolved, and there’s minimal discharge now. You should finish the 7‑day course of valacyclovir and continue the polymyxin/bacitracin ointment until that course is done. You don’t need a separate ophthalmology follow‑up; your primary doctor can monitor it.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay, I’ll keep using the ointment and pills until they’re finished.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your labs today show hemoglobin 9.3, hematocrit 28.9, white count 3.3, platelets 181. Creatinine is 4.1, BUN 20, potassium 3.9, and your INR is 1.6 with a PTT around 96. We’re getting closer to the INR goal, and your kidney numbers look good post‑dialysis.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So I still need both the drip and the pills for now?

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes, for now. Once your INR is in the 2–3 range and stable, we’ll stop the heparin drip and you’ll continue warfarin alone. We’re also planning your discharge home with services, and your dialysis unit will draw your INRs and fax them to your providers so we can keep your warfarin dose safe and effective.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’m okay with going home as long as someone helps me keep track of the blood tests and the warfarin dose.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your INR early this morning is 2.2 and your PTT is about 90.6. That means your warfarin is now in the therapeutic range. The team will be stopping your heparin drip soon and keeping you on warfarin alone.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So after they stop the drip, I’ll just be on the warfarin pills? Do I need to change anything I eat?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, we’ll stop the heparin drip now that your INR is therapeutic and keep you on warfarin. With warfarin, it’s important to keep your vitamin K intake consistent—so avoid big sudden changes in foods like leafy greens. We’ll give you written instructions and your dialysis unit will check your INR regularly.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I don’t eat a lot of salads anyway, but I’ll try to keep things the same. Just tell me what dose to take.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your labs this morning show hemoglobin 9.2, hematocrit 28.6, white count 3.9, platelets 187. Creatinine is 5.1, BUN 24, potassium 4.5, and your INR is 3.0 with a PTT of about 142. We’ll adjust your warfarin dose slightly to keep the INR in the 2–3 range, but you’re safe for discharge today.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’re planning to discharge you home with visiting nurse services today. Your right leg swelling has resolved, your eye infection has nearly cleared, and your dialysis catheter is functioning well. You’ll continue your home hemodialysis schedule, your HIV medications and prophylaxis, your pain and itch medicines, and now warfarin 6 mg daily. Your dialysis unit will draw your INR and fax the results to your providers as ordered.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you. I’m glad the leg and my eye are better. I’ll go to dialysis like usual and make sure they do the blood tests. I just want to stay out of the hospital if I can.

speaker: NURSE
text: Here are your discharge instructions and medication list. It includes your HIV meds, dialysis‑related meds, eye ointment and valacyclovir to finish the 7‑day course, your pain medicines, and warfarin 6 mg daily. It also explains when your dialysis unit should draw your INR and where to fax the results. Do you have any questions before we arrange your ride home?

speaker: PATIENT
text: No, I think I understand. I’ll follow up with my primary doctor and the clinic like it says. Thanks to all of you for taking care of me.
